question_stem: The graph of \(y = g(x)\) is defined for \(-4 \le x \le 4\) and has a maximum point at \((2, 5)\) and a minimum point at \((-1, -2)\).

parts.question_text: State the coordinates of the maximum and minimum points of the graph \(y = g(-x)\).
parts.solution_text:
The transformation \(y = g(-x)\) reflects the graph of \(y = g(x)\) in the \(y\)-axis.  Therefore, the \(x\)-coordinates of any point are multiplied by \(-1\), while the \(y\)-coordinates remain unchanged.

The maximum point \((2, 5)\) of \(y = g(x)\) transforms to \((-2, 5)\) on the graph of \(y = g(-x)\).

The minimum point \((-1, -2)\) of \(y = g(x)\) transforms to \((1, -2)\) on the graph of \(y = g(-x)\).

Therefore, the maximum point of \(y = g(-x)\) is \((-2, 5)\) and the minimum point is \((1, -2)\).
